metadata.case_name: Shyam Lal v. President of India

facts.text: The appellant passed his Civil Engineering degree examination from the Thomason College, Roorkee, in 1922. He stood first in order of merit and carried away the Gold Medal and other prizes awarded to the best student of that year.
He was appointed by the Secretary of State for India in Council to the Indian Service of Engineers as an Assistant Executive Engineer with effect from the 20th October, 1923.
The conditions governing the appellant's terms of appointment, promotion, leave, pension, etc., will be found recorded in a letter issued from India Office, London, on the 13th February, 1924.
He was posted in the United Provinces.
In 1944 the appellant was promoted to the rank of officiating Superintending Engineer.

After the attainment of independence by India a fresh agreement was entered into by and between the appellant the Governor of the United Provinces and the Governor General of India on the 16th September, 1948 confirming the appellant's terms of appointment contained in the letter of the 13th February, 1924.

At or about this time the appellant along with several other officers was recommended by the Chief Engineer for confirmation as Superintending Engineer. The appellant, however, was not confirmed but continued to officiate as Superintending Engineer until the time hereinafter stated.

On the 4th January, 1950, the Public Works Department of the U.P. Government addressed a letter to the Chief Engineer, Irrigation Branch U.P. requesting him to communicate the letter enclosed therewith to the appellant and to ask him to submit as early as possible whatever explanation he might desire to give. The enclosed letter called upon the appellant to show cause within three weeks why he should not be compulsorily retired under the provisions of article 465-A, Civil Service Regulations, as it appeared (1) that he had been making systematic and gross overpayments apparently for no other reason than to benefit the contractors concerned and (2) that he had spent large amounts of public money for his own personal convenience and (3) that he had taken recourse to devious and unscrupulous methods. No less than six instances on which these charges were based were then set out.

The covering letter concluded with the following remarks: Under the rules Government reserve the right to compulsorily retire any officer whose retention in service they consider not to be in the public interest. This is not, therefore, a formal enquiry under the Classification, Control and Appeal Rules but before taking the action indicated above Government were pleased to give an opportunity to Shri Shyam Lal, I.S.E., to show cause why he should not be compulsorily retired.

A copy of the letter of the 4th January, 1950, together with a copy of the enclosure was sent to the appellant with the request that his explanation might be forwarded within the period mentioned by the Government.

The appellant submitted his explanations which, together with the Chief Engineer's comments thereon, were placed before the Union Public Service Commission. The Commission came to the conclusion that five out of the six charges had been proved and submitted their report accordingly.

On the 17th April, 1953, the President, after considering the case and the recommendations of the Commission, decided that the appellant should retire forthwith from service under Note I to article 465-A of the Civil Service Regulations.

Before this order could be served on him the appellant on the 24th April, 1953, filed before the Allahabad High Court a petition under article 226 of the Constitution praying that the order made by the President on the 17th April, 1953, be quashed on the ground, inter alia, that the order was illegal and void in that it was made without affording him any opportunity to show cause against the action proposed to be taken in regard to him.

The High Court by its judgment dated the 1st October, 1953, dismissed the application but, as the case involved a substantial question of the interpretation of the Constitution, the High Court granted leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court.
The appellant had completed 25 years qualifying service.

legal_issues.text: Whether article 465-A of the Civil Service Regulations is applicable to or binding on the appellant
Whether compulsory retirement is nothing but removal from service and the provisions of article 311 of the Constitution apply to the case of compulsory retirement

Whether Note I to article 465-A of the Civil Service Regulations, in so far as it confers on the Government an absolute right to retire an officer, who has completed twenty-five years qualifying service without giving any reason, is repugnant to article 311 of the Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Article 465-A of the Civil Service Regulations is not applicable to or binding on the appellant because it was not in operation at the time of the Government of India Act, 1919, not validated by s.96B(4), not made by Secretary of State in Council, and pension rules could not be delegated under s.96B(2).
Compulsory retirement is nothing but removal from service within the meaning of article 311 and requires opportunity to show cause; the order was made without affording such opportunity.
Note I to article 465-A confers absolute right to retire without reason, repugnant to article 311.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Civil Service Regulations Article 465-A Note 1; Constitution Article 311

respondent_arguments.text: Article 465-A is valid and applicable; rule 7 and 26 of Civil Services Classification, Control and Appeal Rules impress validity upon it.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Civil Services Classification, Control and Appeal Rules r.7,26

respondent_arguments.text: Compulsory retirement under Note 1 to Art 465-A is not removal or dismissal attracting Art 311; it is in public interest, no stigma, pension benefits retained.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Civil Service Regulations Art 465-A Note 1; Constitution Art 311

court_reasoning.text: Article 465-A and Note 1 derived from Resolution No.1085-E.A. of 15th November 1919, in force before Government of India Act 1919 passed on 23rd Dec 1919, validated by s.96B(4); subsequent incorporation in CSR in 1920 was for clarity, not new rule. Government retains existing right to retire after 25 years service in public interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: New rules of 1919 applied to appellant on appointment in 1923; Note 1 assumes existing right aliunde.

court_reasoning.text: Compulsory retirement not dismissal or removal under Art 311: no imputation of misconduct (though opportunity given here to assess public interest); not a penalty under CCA Rules r.49; retains earned pension benefits unlike dismissal/removal; loss of future prospects not punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Removal implies blameworthiness; compulsory retirement requires only 25 years service and public interest.

court_reasoning.text: Note 1 to Art 465-A not repugnant to Art 311 as it does not involve dismissal/removal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art 311 applies only to dismissal/removal/reduction, not all terminations.

holdings.text: Article 465-A and Note 1 applicable to appellant as validated by Government of India Act 1919 s.96B(4).
Compulsory retirement under Note 1 to Art 465-A is not dismissal or removal and does not attract Art 311(2).
Note 1 to Art 465-A not repugnant to Art 311.

precedents_cited.relevance: Held that s.96B(1) 1919 Act did not qualify Crown's pleasure to dismiss; remedy not lawsuit but official appeal.
Similar to Rangachari; rules ineffective against Crown's power pre-1935 Act.
Removal within s.240(3) of 1935 Act, akin to dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satischandra Anand v. The Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Art 311 not apply to all terminations; contract termination not dismissal/removal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal under Art 132; writ under 226; tenure during pleasure Art 310; protection against dismissal/removal Art 311.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Service Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied to Indian Service of Engineers; retiring pension; absolute right to retire after 25 years in public interest without reasons.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1919
statutes_cited.relevance: Validated existing rules including pension rules of 1919 Resolution; power to make service rules.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Tenure during pleasure; no dismissal by subordinate authority; reasonable opportunity before dismissal/reduction.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Services (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Penalties including removal/dismissal; procedure for inquiry; not formal inquiry here.

outcome.summary: The appeal against the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition challenging the President's order of compulsory retirement under Note 1 to Article 465-A CSR is dismissed. The Court holds the rule valid and applicable, and compulsory retirement not attracting Article 311.

key_quotes.text: Government retains an absolute right to retire any officer after he has completed twenty-five years qualifying service without giving any reasons, and no claim to special compensation on this account will be entertained.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Note 1 to Art 465-A CSR, central to the power exercised.

key_quotes.text: A compulsory retirement has no stigma or implication of misbehaviour or incapacity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes compulsory retirement from dismissal/removal under Art 311.

key_quotes.text: One retains only what one already possesses and the word retain is wholly inappropriate for the purpose of conferring a fresh right.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains Note 1 assumes pre-existing right from 1919 rules.

key_quotes.text: Every termination of service does not amount to dismissal or removal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on scope of Art 311.
